Section.Description: Structure depictions and information for 2D, 3D, and crystal related
Record identifiers, synonyms, chemical names, descriptors, etc.
Descriptors generated from chemical structure input
Chemical name computed from chemical structure that uses International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC) nomenclature standards.
International Chemical Identifier (InChI) computed from chemical structure using the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC) standard.
International Chemical Identifier hash (InChIKey) computed from chemical structure using the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC) standard.
Simplified Molecular-Input Line-Entry System (SMILES) computed from chemical structure devoid of isotopic and stereochemical information.
Important identifiers assigned to this chemical substance by authoritative organizations
A proprietary registry number assigned by the Chemical Abstracts Service (CAS) division of the American Chemical Society (ACS) often used to help describe chemical ingredients.
A non-proprietary registry number assigned by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) known as an UNique Ingredient Identifier (UNII) code.
Substance identifier at the Distributed Structure-Searchable Toxicity (DSSTox) Database.
Links to Wikipedia or wikidata for this record.

Alternative names for this PubChem Compound record.  A compound can have many different names.  For example, acetone (CH3C(=O)CH3) is also known as propanone, propan-2-one, or dimethyl ketone.  The brand name of a product is commonly used to indicate the primary chemical ingredient(s) in the product (e.g., Tylenol, a common pain killer, is often used for acetaminophen, its active ingredient).  Another example of common synonyms is record identifiers used in different data collections, such as Chemical Abstract Service (CAS) registry numbers, FDA UNII (Unique Ingredient Identifiers), and many others.  All these various names and identifiers that designate this compound are organized under the Synonyms section.

Medical Subject Heading (MeSH) names or identifiers matching this PubChem Compound record.  The matching between the MeSH and compound records is performed by name matching (i.e., identical common names).

Chemical names provided by individual data contributors. Synonyms of Substances corresponding to a PubChem Compound record are combined. Some contributed names may be considered erroneous and filtered out. The link on each synonym shows which depositors provided that particular synonym for this structure.
Chemical and physical properties such as melting point, molecular weight, etc.
Properties computed automatically from the given chemical structure

Molecular weight or molecular mass refers to the mass of a molecule. It is calculated as the sum of the mass of each constituent atom multiplied by the number of atoms of that element in the molecular formula.
Hydrogen Bond Donor count
Hydrogen Bond Acceptor count
Rotatable bond is defined as any single non-ring bond, bounded to nonterminal heavy (i.e., non-hydrogen) atom.
The exact mass of an isotopic species is obtained by summing the masses of the individual isotopes of the molecule.

The monoisotopic mass is the sum of the masses of the atoms in a molecule using the unbound, ground-state, rest mass of the principal (most abundant) isotope for each element instead of the isotopic average mass.
The topological polar surface area (TPSA) of a molecule is defined as the surface sum over all polar atoms in a molecule.
A heavy atom is defined as any atom except hydrogen in a chemical structure.

Formal charge is the difference between the number of valence electrons of each atom and the number of electrons the atom is associated with. Formal charge assumes any shared electrons are equally shared between the two bonded atoms.

The complexity rating of a compound is a rough estimate of how complicated a structure is, seen from both the point of view of the elements contained and the displayed structural features including symmetry. This complexity rating is computed using the Bertz/Hendrickson/Ihlenfeldt formula.

Isotopte Atom Count is the number of isotopes that are not most abundant for the corresponding chemical elements.  Isotopes are variants of a chemical element which differ in neutron number.  For example, among three isotopes of carbon (i.e., C-12, C-13, and C-14), the isotope atom count considers the C-13 and C-14 atoms, because C-12 is the most abundant isotope of carbon.

An atom stereocenter, also known as a chiral center, is an atom that is attached to four different types of atoms (or groups of atoms) in the tetrahedral arrangement. It can have either (R)- or (S)- configurations.  Some compounds, such as racemic mixtures, have an undefined atom stereocenter, whose (R/S)-configuration is not specifically defined.

An atom stereocenter, also known as a chiral center, is an atom that is attached to four different types of atoms (or groups of atoms) in the tetrahedral arrangement. It can have either (R)- or (S)- configurations.  Some compounds, such as racemic mixtures, have an undefined atom stereocenter, whose (R/S)-configuration is not specifically defined.

A bond stereocenter is a non-rotatable bond around which two atoms can have different arrangement (as in cis- and trans-forms of butene around its double bond).  Some compounds have an undefined bond stereocenter, whose stereochemistry is not specifically defined.

A bond stereocenter is a non-rotatable bond around which two atoms can have different arrangement (as in cis- and trans-forms of butene around its double bond).  Some compounds have an undefined bond stereocenter, whose stereochemistry is not specifically defined.
Covalently-Bonded Unit Count
Compound is canonicalized
Properties determined experimentally (See also Safety and Hazard Properties section for more information if available)
Physical description refers to the appearance or features of a given chemical compound including color, odor, state, taste and more in general
The decomposition temperature of a substance is the temperature at which the substance chemically decomposes

StringWithMarkup.String: When heated to decomposition it emits toxic fumes of phosphoxides and Na2O.

Reference: Lewis, R.J. Sax's Dangerous Properties of Industrial Materials. 9th ed. Volumes 1-3. New York, NY: Van Nostrand Reinhold, 1996., p. 2968

StringWithMarkup.String: WHEN HEATED TO DECOMP, CAN EMIT HIGHLY TOXIC FUMES OF PO(X).

Reference: Lewis, R.J. Sax's Dangerous Properties of Industrial Materials. 9th ed. Volumes 1-3. New York, NY: Van Nostrand Reinhold, 1996., p. 2968

Section.Description: Additional property information.

StringWithMarkup.String: CLEAR, HYGROSCOPIC GLASS; MP 628 °C; SOL IN WATER, BUT DISSOLVES SLOWLY; DEPOLYMERIZES IN AQ SOLN TO FORM SODIUM TRIMETAPHOSPHATE & SODIUM ORTHOPHOSPHATES. /POLYMERIC SODIUM METAPHOSPHATES/

Reference: Budavari, S. (ed.). The Merck Index - Encyclopedia of Chemicals, Drugs and Biologicals. Rahway, NJ: Merck and Co., Inc., 1989., p. 1240

StringWithMarkup.String: SOL IN WATER; INSOL IN ORG SOLVENTS. /SODIUM HEXAMETAPHOSPHATE DETERGENTS/

Reference: Budavari, S. (ed.). The Merck Index - Encyclopedia of Chemicals, Drugs and Biologicals. Rahway, NJ: Merck and Co., Inc., 1989., p. 1240

StringWithMarkup.String: It possesses sequestering, dispersing, and flocculating properties and precipitates proteins. In very low concentrations, it inhibits corrosion in steel and prevents the precipitation of slightly soluble, scale-forming compounds such as calcium carbonate and calcium sulfate. /Calgon/

Reference: Lewis, R.J., Sr (Ed.). Hawley's Condensed Chemical Dictionary. 12th ed. New York, NY: Van Nostrand Rheinhold Co., 1993, p. 210

StringWithMarkup.String: Depolymerizes in aqueous soln to form sodium trimetaphosphate and sodium orthophosphates.

Reference: Budavari, S. (ed.). The Merck Index - An Encyclopedia of Chemicals, Drugs, and Biologicals. Whitehouse Station, NJ: Merck and Co., Inc., 1996., p. 1481

StringWithMarkup.String: Miscible in water, but insoluble in organic solvents. /Calgon/

Reference: Lewis, R.J., Sr (Ed.). Hawley's Condensed Chemical Dictionary. 12th ed. New York, NY: Van Nostrand Rheinhold Co., 1993, p. 210

Section.Description: Spectral data for chemical compounds
Infrared spectroscopy (IR spectroscopy) is the spectroscopy that deals with the infrared region of the electromagnetic spectrum.
